item.source: Harry Potter and the deathly hallows

item.title: Harry Potter and the deathly hallows
item.dc:creator: TheeGoatPig
item.description:
when I was growing up I was always wondering why there was no violence and death in any of the stories we were reading, yet I enjoyed all of the violence and death in the movies I was watching.

I haven’t read the books, but I have enjoyed each movie more than the last. I loved the battle between Dumbledore and Voldemort in… Whichever movie that was… I thought that was what all wizard battles before it had wanted to be, but failed miserably at attaining.

I don’t spend money on them though. I wait for them to come onto cable TV so that I can watch them there. I broke this rule with half Blood Prince, but only because I saw half of it on the flight back from Las Vegas and really wanted to see the rest of it, and didn’t want to wait the six months for it to come to cable, so I rented it.

Even though I want to see the next one, I will be waiting for cable again most likely.

Read full topic
item.source: Harry Potter and the deathly hallows

That’s probably what your mom thought and you find her creepy.

item.title: Harry Potter and the deathly hallows
item.dc:creator: DansonDelta40
item.description:
DiePoente:

I don’t think that 12 years old kids should read them. Many people die in them…

Same goes for every fairy tale out there. Children like it when people in stories die. Especially the bad guys. If good guys die, it makes children all the more vengeful against the bad guys, and they are all the more satisfied with bad guys coming to violent ends then.

Seriously, grow up! Children can cope with a lot more violence and sex than you would imagine.

Read full topic

item.title: Harry Potter and the deathly hallows
item.dc:creator: eateroftheflame
item.description:
Cobra:

Then explain “NOT MY DAUGHTER YOU BITCH” In the 7th book and “YOU FILTHY,
STINKING,
IDIOTIC, B----” in the 3rd book.

What do you mean explain it, I just said it matured as it went along but it was always intended to be kid’s series. JK Rowling was just so brilliant that adults ended up liking them as well.

Edit: Ok how about this “In 1997 to 1998 Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone won almost all the UK awards judged by children, but none of the children’s book awards judged by adults”
